4_401.text: On return to office, we will instigate a review of the entire economic regulatory environment.

4_402.text: This review will be designed to ensure that the existing regulatory regime is operating efficiently, is balancing the needs of users with the requirements of producers and is not imposing excessive costs on the economy.

4_403.text: Recognising the importance of small business to our economy, Fianna Fáil will continue to support and enhance the Business Expansion and Seed Capital Schemes.

4_404.text: We recognise the vital role played by low taxes in our economic success.

4_405.text: We guarantee that the 12.5% rate of corporation tax will not be changed.

4_406.text: We will resolutely oppose any attempt to introduce tax harmonisation within the European Union, either directly or through technical measures.

4_407.text: Under Fianna Fáil, Ireland’s dynamic and flexible economy will continue to be one of the most attractive locations in the world to invest, to employ and to do business in.

4_408.text: A Fair Tax System We have overhauled the taxation system over the past ten years through dramatic and sustainable cuts in rates and increases in tax credits.

4_409.text: However further progress can be made in making the system even fairer.

4_410.text: Subject to the controlling economic and fiscal framework, Fianna Fáil in government will implement the following specific approach to tax: Our first priority remains low and middle income earners – therefore our first task will be to use tax credits and bands to keep low income earners out of the standard rate band and average earners out of the higher band.

4_411.text: PRSI, as currently devised, is not a fair tax as it is not levied on incomes above €48,800.

4_412.text: Consequently, it is most lightly borne by those on the highest incomes.

4_413.text: To eliminate this inequity, Fianna Fáil will abolish the PRSI ceiling for full rate payers and reduce the rate at which this tax is levied from 4% to 2% over the lifetime of the next administration.

4_414.text: We will also reduce the rate of PRSI paid by the self employed to 2% from 3%.

4_415.text: These moves will eliminate remaining inequality in the income tax system and enhance its progressive nature.

4_416.text: The Social Insurance Fund will be reimbursed by the Exchequer for the cost of this reform.

4_417.text: Once these commitments are met, any additional resources will be targeted at further enhancing the rewards of work.

4_418.text: Specifically, we are committed to reducing the standard rate of income tax to 18% and the higher rate of income tax to 40% over the lifetime of the next government if economic resources allow.

4_419.text: We will introduce measures to further weight VRT in favour of cars with lower emissions.

4_420.text: Supporting Home Ownership While Protecting House Values and Jobs Fianna Fáil is determined to help first-time buyers directly and substantially without disturbing market conditions, driving increases in house prices, and putting the more than 260,000 jobs in construction at risk.

4_421.text: Our approach is good for certainty, good for affordability, good for society and good for the economy.

4_422.text: As the Housing chapter explains in more detail, in government we will legislate immediately to abolish stamp duty for all first-time buyers and make this change retrospective for all deeds presented for stamping to the Revenue Commissioners on or after 30th April 2007.

4_423.text: Implement major changes in mortgage interest relief for first-time buyersand those who bought a house in the past seven years.

4_424.text: Keeping Ireland Working Jobs, Skills & Advanced Research Since 1997 no less than 600,000 jobs have been created in the Irish economy, one in four of all jobs.

4_425.text: The most remarkable part of this has been the level of well-paid, highly skilled jobs created.

4_426.text: We have gone from having Europe’s highest rate of unemployment to it lowest – with long-term unemployment now down to 1.3%.

4_427.text: This did not happen by chance.

4_428.text: It is the result of the clear choices of a government working in partnership with businesses and employees.

4_429.text: Fianna Fáil policies have always been pro-education, pro-business, and pro-low taxes, both at personal, and at corporate level.

4_430.text: The 12.5% corporate tax rate has enabled the Irish economy to perform very strongly over the past 10 years and is much admired internationally.

4_431.text: Ireland’s level of Foreign Direct Investment is now proportionately one of the highest in the world, with over 1,000 overseas companies having substantial international operations in Ireland.

4_432.text: Our Small and Medium Enterprise sector is also very strong, employing over 800,000 people.

4_433.text: The Next Steps Forward for Keeping Ireland Working

4_434.text: We fully accept that we can take nothing for granted – that other countries will keep trying to catch up with us.

4_435.text: Low-tax, high-investment, pro-enterprise policies have led to spectacular progress for our country and we believe that this approach must be built upon.

4_436.text: Fianna Fáil is the party of job creation and we are absolutely committed to maintaining high-levels of good employment, low levels of unemployment and a strong business sector.

4_437.text: This is why we are proposing a coordinated series of next steps forward to support the creation of 250,000 jobs over the next five years.

4_439.text: Overall, we will implement policies which fit within a key set of principles: Keep taxes on employment low.

4_440.text: Where possible reduce the regulatory burden faced by business.

4_441.text: Significantly upskill the Irish workforce at all levels.

4_443.text: Develop a growing focus on the dynamic SME sector.

4_444.text: Ensure that employment standards are met throughout the economy.

4_445.text: Tax and Regulation We have championed and delivered a low-tax environment for business and we have worked to reduce the regulatory burden faced by business.

4_446.text: We will continue to do so and, in government we will: Ensure that our regulatory framework remains flexible, proportionate and up to date.

4_447.text: Keep Ireland’s Corporation Tax at its current level at most and veto any EU proposal which might undermine this.

4_448.text: Continue to enhance the Business Expansion Scheme and the Seed Capital Scheme.

4_449.text: Examine measures to limit the ability of local authorities to impose punitive charges on local businesses.

4_450.text: Implement procedures to ensure direct feedback from business on regulatory burdens and publish annual reports on how these issues have been addressed.

4_451.text: Small & Medium Enterprises We view small business as big business for Ireland.

4_452.text: There are over 250,000 small businesses operating across the country, which employ a total of over 800,000 people or 40% of the workforce.

4_453.text: This number is also growing – businesses up by 50% and employment by 79% in recent years.

4_454.text: We are committed to helping SMEs grow, becoming more knowledge-based and being a key driver of future success.

4_455.text: In government we will: Encourage financial institutions to provide European Investment.

4_456.text: Fund guaranteed loan finance to small businesses.

4_457.text: Continue to enhance the Business Expansion Scheme (BES) and the Seed Capital Scheme (SCS) following on from changes introduced in Budget 2007.

4_458.text: Make Innovation Vouchers available to small businesses in every sector, to be exchanged for advice, expertise and information from accredited knowledge providers.

4_459.text: This will build on the initiative taken this year when Ireland became only the second country in Europe to introduce this scheme to help small businesses.

4_460.text: Actively encourage more “Competence Centres” which will bring together companies that have similar research problems and team them with highly qualified researchers to produce new technologies, bring their results to market and deliver a competitive advantage to Irish industry.

4_461.text: Provide Knowledge Acquisition Grants to enable small businesses in the manufacturing and internationally traded service sectors to gain access to research-based knowledge, expertise and facilities in higher education institutes.

4_462.text: Manufacturing The manufacturing sector faces many serious challenges, but has maintained significant employment levels in recent years.

4_463.text: To help the sector to compete more effectively, in government we will: Assist smaller manufacturing firms to realise the potential of information technology by appointing a Director for the R&D programme support structures.

4_464.text: Support upskilling of low-skilled workers in the manufacturing sector by investing more than 32.8 billion over the next six years in upskilling.

4_465.text: Fully co-operate with the High Level Group on Manufacturing established under Towards 2016.

4_466.text: Ensure better exploitation of domestic opportunities to facilitate companies in applying for public sector contracts.

4_467.text: Support the change process in companies through advice and assistance.

4_468.text: Support the establishment of R&D units in manufacturing companies.

4_469.text: Competition and Consumer Protection We believe that competition and consumer protection are essential parts of maintaining a vibrant economy.

4_470.text: We are determined to ensure that competition thrives and that costs to the consumer are kept to a minimum.

4_471.text: In government we will: Ensure that prices of goods are labelled and transparent so the consumer is well-informed.

4_472.text: Make consumers more aware of their rights through information campaigns and through the education system.

4_473.text: Prevent consumers from being charged extra for using a particular method of payment of their choice - either cash, credit or debit card.

4_474.text: Maintain the ban on Pyramid selling and ensure that penalties are enforced which includes 3500,000 fines and /or imprisonment.

4_475.text: On-the-spot fines will be introduced for breaches of consumer law.

4_476.text: Ensure that Consumer Codes of Conducts are published by businesses.

4_477.text: Ensure that the National Consumers’ Agency is accessible to all people who have queries or complaints via low-cost calls or web-sites.

4_478.text: Enforcement will be a core focus of the Agency.

4_479.text: Ensure product safety by operating the EU Rapex scheme.

4_480.text: Make sure that the needs of the consumer and national competitiveness are fully accounted for in the pricing decisions of regulators.

4_481.text: Regulate property management companies to ensure that the interests of consumers are protected.

4_482.text: Managing Economic Migration We are determined to manage economic migration in a way that protects the rights of all workers, maintains unemployment at the lowest possible level and ensures successful integration.

4_483.text: Fianna Fáil in government will: Continue to issue green cards in respect of occupations where there are skills shortages, including those for example in the information technology, biopharma, engineering and health sectors.

4_484.text: Only grant work permits where it can be demonstrated, following a rigorous labour market test, that suitable employees are not available within the EEA.

4_485.text: Allow workers to apply for and reapply for their own permit and to transfer to another employment in cases of mistreatment.

4_486.text: We will also provide for spouses of employment permit holders who are granted residence in Ireland to be granted an employment permit.

4_487.text: Ensure that the employment rights of non-EEA students are protected by requiring them to have work permits which will allow them to work for a maximum of 20 hours a week.

4_488.text: Re-establish an Intra-Company transfer scheme for temporary trans-national top management transfers to enable companies to meet short-term needs.

4_489.text: Ensure that employment permit applications are not approved for wages below the REA/ERO rate or the National Minimum Wage, and that there is full enforcement of employment law to protect workers from being abused.

4_490.text: Increase the number of Labour Inspectors to 90.

4_491.text: Ensure that workers are made aware of their rights through initiatives such as printing the minimum wage on the work permit and providing information in a range of languages.

4_492.text: Protect employees against employers deducting recruitment expenses from pay and retaining workers personal documents.

4_493.text: Skills for the Future Fianna Fáil will guarantee that our workforce becomes more skilled at all levels to ensure that we make the transition to a competitive, innovation-driven, knowledge-based economy.

4_494.text: To achieve this objective we will invest over 37.7 billion over the next 6 years in training and skills development and will: Expand the role of FÁS and Enterprise Ireland to increase the “employer commitment” to training, particularly in the SME sector.

4_495.text: Invest in SME owner/manager Development Programmes.

4_496.text: Expand the Competency Development Programmes, allowing more workers across all ectors and company sizes the opportunity to upskill.

4_497.text: Fund Regional Skills Advisory Groups which consist of both firms and education/training providers so that the needs of each region are met.

4_498.text: Utilise the National Training Fund to assist companies in improving their employees’ skill sets.

4_499.text: Ensure that FÁS expands the Excellence Through People programmes (ETP) to reach 500,000 workers by 2020.

4_500.text: Expand the Training Networks Programme which will increase the number of training grants given to companies and the Skillsnet Training programme which allows companies to access training Make it easier to access FÁS apprenticeship programmes by increasing the number of places across the country.

4_501.text: We will add to the number of occupations to ensure the continued skills relevance and we will do this in consultation with the Social Partners We are also committed to updating the present apprenticeship programmes to keep them responsive, competitive and productive.

4_502.text: Keeping Ireland Ahead at the Cutting Edge Ireland cannot be successful in the future without sustained investment in developing skills and ideas through research and development.

4_503.text: Under this Fianna Fáil-led Government, research and development spending has soared and is crucial to attracting significant international investment.

4_504.text: Investment in indigenous R&D is important as Ireland is now rated second in the world for the number of science graduates per 100,000 25-34 year olds in employment.

4_505.text: We live in a new Ireland - prosperous but not without its challenges.

4_506.text: The deeper our economic success and the longer it is sustained, the greater the challenges to keep the forward momentum.

4_507.text: While Fianna Fáil works to maintain it, we will also take the next steps to introduce greater opportunity for even more people to become involved in our economy and to benefit from its success.

4_508.text: The biggest contributor to our economic success has been the exceptional wealth of the intellectual capital available to native and overseas investors.

4_509.text: Ireland renowned for the quality of its graduates.

4_510.text: The basis for future growth in prosperity and jobs is further investment in the knowledge, skills and innovation capacity up to fourth level that will drive economic and social development in an increasing competitive global environment.

4_511.text: The higher education system must deliver people who will expand knowledge-based business in Ireland.

4_512.text: This will require change and quality improvements in our Universities and Institutes of Education across all key disciplines.

4_513.text: Fianna Fáil will actively promote a system-wide form of collaboration that draws on the collective strengths of all our 3rd level colleges.

4_514.text: This collaboration will enable companies, both large and small, to access new knowledge, specialist skills and the latest technologies.

4_515.text: We have already started this process by publishing the Strategy for Science, Technology and Innovation which for the first time outlines an “all Government” approach to R&D across nine departments.

4_516.text: This involves investing over 38.2 billion up to 2013 across sectors such as Health, Agri-food, Energy, Marine, Geoscience and Environmental research.

4_517.text: All of these sectors are huge employers and contribute billions to the economy.

4_518.text: This investment will provide for the continued development of a world class research system, underpinned by the essential physical infrastructure and human resources with the number of PhD graduates set to almost double over the next six years.

4_519.text: In government Fianna Fáil will continue the upward investment to enable Ireland to compete seriously as a “Knowledge Economy”.

4_520.text: Over the next five years we will: Double investment in R&D. Fully implement the Strategy on Science Technology and Innovation.

4_521.text: Ensure doubling of PhDs in Science, Engineering and Technology.

4_522.text: Simplify grants and supports to businesses to conduct R&D. Double the spending on BERD (Business Expenditure on R&D) by 2013.

4_523.text: Enhance the R&D Tax credit scheme.

4_524.text: Ensure that there is enhanced industry/academia collaboration to benefit business and secure growth.

4_525.text: Social Partnership and the Public Sector Social Partnership has made a critical contribution to Ireland’s economic and social development over the last twenty years.

4_526.text: It has transformed our industrial relations landscape and has created a broader forum for the consideration of policy.

4_527.text: It has created opportunities for the resolution of issues in a way which has supported rather than impaired economic and social development.

4_528.text: Our leader, Taoiseach Bertie Ahern TD, is the architect of social partnership and understands better than anyone how to reconcile the interests of employers, employees and other groups to agree a shared agenda for progress.

4_529.text: Fianna Fáil also understands that a partnership approach with public sector workers is central to achieving improvements in public services.

4_530.text: In government, we have sought to ensure that services are delivered to the citizens who pay for them in a modern and accessible way by public servants who are well rewarded for their work.

4_531.text: There has been substantial reform in the manner in which public services are planned and delivered – and equally there has been a substantial increase in the numbers and remuneration of public servants.

4_532.text: The Next Steps Forward for Social Partnership and the Public Sector Fianna Fáil believes that maintaining industrial peace through a strong Social Partnership system and promoting efficiency in the delivery of public services are central to protecting and growing our social and economic prosperity in the years ahead.

4_533.text: This is why we are proposing a series of next steps forward on social partnership and the public sector.

4_534.text: Social Partnership Fianna Fáil established Social Partnership and we are determined to maintain its success in the years ahead by: Working with the social partners to ensure the full implementation of the Towards 2016 Agreement.

4_535.text: Ensuring that pay improvements for public sector workers continue to be linked to delivery and verification of agreed improvements in public services.

4_536.text: Ensuring Value for Money Evaluation, improvement in performance and constant modernisation have become part and parcel of people’s working lives in the private sector.

4_537.text: We will ensure that the delivery of services in the public sector are evaluated and improved in similar ways.

4_538.text: The public has a legitimate right to expect public services to be delivered in an effective manner – in terms of both time and money – and for the right activities to get priority.

4_539.text: The bulk of capital projects are now being delivered on or below budget and, in some instances, ahead of schedule.

4_540.text: Building on this performance, all expenditure under the NDP 2007-2013 will be subject, as appropriate, to a robust Value for Money framework.

4_541.text: Key elements of this framework include: All projects will subject to project appraisal to ensure that NDP programme objectives and Value for Money are being achieved; All capital projects over 330 million will require a full cost benefit analysis in line with the Department of Finance guidelines of February 2005; New procurement arrangements which will deliver greater cost certainty for public capital projects; NDP Programme Evaluations and Value for Money and Policy Reviews will be published and submitted to the relevant Select Committees of the Oireachtas; and As provided for under the Budget and Estimates Reform proposals set out in Budget 2006, all Ministers will submit an Annual Output Statement with their Annual Estimates to the relevant Oireachtas Committee.

4_542.text: This will detail target outputs for the Estimates and the following years’ Statement will set out achievements against target.

4_543.text: This process will encompass Exchequer funded NDP spending.

4_544.text: This robust and transparent process will be augmented by the new requirement for the submission of an Annual Report on NDP progress to the Oireachtas where it will be subject to debate.

4_545.text: Other factors such as the Strategic Infrastructure Act 2006 and extra judicial resources will also impact positively on value for money, delivery and Implementation.

4_546.text: Delivering the Government Programme Fianna Fáil believes setting up a new Delivery Unit in the Department of the Taoiseach will help to ensure that delivery of the Government programme is on track, with early identification of obstacles so that steps can be taken to rectify them.

4_547.text: The Unit will be tasked with: Monitoring and reporting on delivery of the Government Programme.

4_548.text: Developing annual Government Programme delivery targets.

4_549.text: Facilitating the sharing of knowledge regarding best practice and value for money in project delivery throughout Government departments.

4_550.text: Providing the Cabinet with monthly progress updates on the implementation on the Government Programme.

4_551.text: Public Sector Management Fianna Fáil will help to foster in the public sector an entrepreneurial spirit, focussed on finding opportunities to improve services for the Irish public.

4_552.text: Reform and modernisation should be part of an ongoing process that keeps pace with the needs of Irish society and creates a public sector work environment where talent is valued and performance is recognised.

4_553.text: Fianna Fáil in government will: Support the further opening up of management roles to the best qualified candidates.

4_554.text: Roll out the new Performance Management and Development System (PMDS).

4_555.text: It is an essential tool for managing performance and career development for all staff.

4_556.text: A consistent evaluation system should identify outstanding performance and highlight underperformance.

4_557.text: Implement improvements in human resource management which ensure that all public servants are helped to develop to the best of their ability.

4_558.text: Support succession and career planning to ensure a talent pipeline for thefuture leadership of the public sector.

4_559.text: Decentralisation In 2003 we launched the largest programme of decentralisation in the history of our civil and public service.

4_560.text: This programme is designed to meet the need for balanced regional development, relieve pressures on Dublin, give public servants a greater opportunity to choose the communities they live and work in and to allow for a clustering approach which ensures effective management.

4_561.text: We accept that the initial timetables were too ambitious and that completing the programme will take more work.

4_562.text: However, we remain absolutely committed to decentralisation and to the towns designated to host offices.

4_563.text: Fianna Fáil in government will: Continue to move ahead with decentralisation.

4_564.text: Ensure that no public servant is obliged to accept decentralisation against their wishes and that promotion opportunities remain available.

4_565.text: Transport A modern society needs a modern infrastructure.

4_566.text: Since coming to office, Fianna Fáil in government has moved to correct the impact of decades of under-investment in our transport infrastructure by committing unprecedented development funding to this area.

4_567.text: Our achievements include: An unprecedented upgrading of our road network with clear benefits forquality of life, safety and competitiveness.

4_568.text: Over 200 km of new motorway, 500 km of new dual and single carriageways with over 550km of new roads in construction this year.

4_569.text: A complete overhaul of our rail service in terms of track and new rolling stock.

4_570.text: Over 1,100 new buses for Dublin Bus including 100 delivered over December 2006 and January this year.

4_571.text: Over 600 new buses for Bus Éireann.

4_572.text: QBCs have been introduced successfully in Dublin and are being rolled out in the other cities.

4_573.text: 67 New InterCity carriages with 183 new railcars to be delivered in the next two years.

4_574.text: Our rail fleet will be the youngest in Europe this year.

4_575.text: The success of Luas, carrying over 26 million passengers annually.

4_576.text: A doubling of capacity for passengers on the DART.

4_577.text: A vibrant aviation sector with 200% growth in passenger numbers at the regional airports, 110% more passengers at Dublin, 100% more at Shannon and an increase of 150% at Cork.

4_578.text: More choice for air travellers with a doubling of routes serviced from Dublin, Cork and Shannon.

4_579.text: A reformed road safety regime with penalty points and mandatory alcohol testing successfully in place and the Road Safety Authority established.

4_580.text: Ireland now has one of the world’s most successful economies.

4_581.text: It needs a first rate transport network if it is to sustain and build on that success.

4_582.text: But investment in transport is about more than economics.

4_583.text: A high quality efficient transport system enhances quality of life for all.

4_584.text: That is why Fianna Fáil published and is implementing Transport 21, the first-ever integrated plan for developing transport networks in all parts of the country.

4_585.text: The Next Steps Forward for Transport We are determined to use the undoubted progress of recent years and continue to accelerate actions that will deliver a modern transport system throughout the country.

4_586.text: Therefore we are proposing a series of significant next steps forward for transport in Ireland.

4_587.text: Overall, we will implement a programme of investment and service development which will: Improve safety Deliver real commuting choice Cut travelling times Reduce congestion Public Transport

4_588.text: We are committed to a major increase in the capacity and quality of our public transport services, including the full integration of services.

4_589.text: Enhanced public transport services will help the environment, reduce congestion and improve quality of life for all.

4_590.text: In government we will: Substantially improve and expand Luas services in Dublin by: Joining the Green and Red Luas lines.

4_594.text: Extending Luas from the City Centre to Liffey Junction (Broadstone/Cabra).

4_595.text: Extending Luas to Rathfarnham subject to feasibility study.

4_596.text: Improve rail services by: Reopening the Western Rail Corridor from Ennis to Claremorris.

4_597.text: Examining the feasibility of reopening the line from Claremorris to Sligo.

4_600.text: Opening the Navan rail line, initially to Dunboyne, and prepare for services to Navan.

4_601.text: Accelerating construction of the Interconnector between Docklands and Heuston stations.

4_602.text: Opening Metro North from St Stephen’s Green to Swords via Dublin Airport.

4_603.text: Opening Metro-West connecting Tallaght and Ballymun through Clondalkin, Liffey Valley and Blanchardstown.

4_605.text: Ensuring that the evolving regulatory regime will deliver service improvements by both private and public operators and that the needs of the consumer rather than the operator will be the prime driver of the marketplace.

4_606.text: Continuing to develop Quality Bus Corridors in Dublin and the other cities.

4_607.text: Doubling the length of bus priority schemes to improve the quality, reliability and efficiency of the fleet of buses serving the Greater Dublin Area.

4_608.text: We will continue to promote integrated ticketing and smart card technologies which will allow a differential pricing system to be introduced.

4_609.text: We will also plan and deliver strategies for the future development of integrated public transport in Cork, Limerick, Galway and Waterford, including examining the feasibility of Luas systems in those cities.

4_610.text: Roads The development of a high-quality route network carries significant benefits for our competitiveness, balanced regional development and the safety of our roads.

4_611.text: In government we will complete:The five inter-urban motorways connecting Dublin with Belfast, Cork, Galway, Limerick and Waterford.

4_612.text: The Atlantic Road Corridor connecting Letterkenny and Waterford through Sligo, Charlestown, Tuam, Galway, Gort, Ennis, Limerick, Mallow and Cork to motorway standard on most of the routes.

4_613.text: The Border Road Corridor connecting Dundalk to Sligo via Enniskillen High quality road corridors to the Border, the North West and the West connecting Mullingar and Westport/Ballina/Sligo, Kells and Belturbet, as well as Ardee and Monaghan.

4_614.text: The Eastcoast N11 dual carriageway to Rosslare.

4_615.text: The Dublin to Letterkenny/Derry dual carriageway.

4_617.text: The incoming government will explore an important initiative in the area of funding road development.

4_618.text: Institutional investors and small savers would be given the opportunity to subscribe for an infrastructure bond.

4_619.text: Initially this would be used to fund a rebuilding of the Dublin to Letterkenny/Derry road and the Dublin Outer Orbital Route subject to feasibility and planning.

4_620.text: An index-linked infrastructure bond would be issued by the National Development Finance Agency and set to mature in 50 years time with a fixed coupon.

4_621.text: Using risk distribution in line with Eurostat rules, the bond would be structured as off balance sheet financing.

4_622.text: The bond would be issued in increments to match capital expenditure as it occurs.

4_623.text: It would allow the people of Ireland to invest securely in our future without adding to the National Debt.

4_624.text: Road Safety In spite of dramatic increases in the number of cars on Irish roads, 2006 saw the second best year for road safety in four decades.

4_625.text: In our next steps for road safety, we will: Maintain progress on driving test waiting times, ensuring that the waiting time does not exceed 8 weeks at any test centre in the country.

4_626.text: Compel persons disqualified for drink driving to re-sit their driving test.

4_627.text: Introduce smart-card learner permits and driving licences.

4_628.text: Introduce compulsory alcohol and drug testing for drivers involved in accidents causing injury.

4_629.text: Aviation In order to support a thriving aviation industry, in government we will: Support the development of Cork and Shannon airports as fully independent entities offering a range of both long-haul and short-haul routes.

4_630.text: Recognising the opportunity presented by Open Skies, encourage the development of new transatlantic services at Shannon.

4_631.text: Open Terminal 2 at Dublin Airport in 2009 Strengthen the role of the regional airports through continuing capital support, encouraging them to play a full part in fostering regional development.

4_632.text: Ports Ports are vital to our economic prosperity, carrying 99% of our exports by volume to the world.

4_633.text: In government, Fianna Fáil will: Continue to support the State-owned commercial port companies as they invest in improving their infrastructure.

4_634.text: Undertake a comprehensive study of the role of Dublin Port taking account of location, overall ports policy, transport policy, urban development and the National Spatial Strategy.

4_635.text: Invest 331 million under the National Development Plan in Regional Harbours to ensure that their potential contribution to the economic and social life of their communities is fully realised.

4_636.text: Regional and Local Roads Fianna Fáil will: Identify key regional roads to be upgraded and will put in place a multi-annual programme, in parallel with Transport 21 to achieve this.

4_637.text: The focus of this programme will be on heavier trafficked routes linking our rural towns with each other and with the national road network.

4_638.text: Spend 34.3 billion on non-national roads under the National Development Plan and in particular accelerate investment in the restoration programme to improve sub-standard roads.

4_639.text: Support the provision of urban distributor routes around major towns with significant contributions from developers as new areas are opened up for development.

4_640.text: Energy A reliable and affordable supply of energy is central to many elements of economic and social life.

4_641.text: Reducing our dependence on certain forms of energy production is also necessary to achieve fundamental environmental objectives which are vital for the future of this island and the world as a whole.

4_642.text: In recent years, there has been a 600% increase in electricity generated by wind on the national grid and Ireland has become one of the leading centres for wave energy research worldwide and ambitious biofuels targets have been set.

4_643.text: Later this year a Single Electricity Market will come into place.

4_644.text: We have also facilitated the creation of a Single Electricity Market which will come into place on 1st November 2007.

4_645.text: Fianna Fáil is committed to securing both long-term energy security and a low carbon future for Ireland.

4_646.text: Our White Paper on Energy – the first in 30 years – sets out how this can be done.

4_647.text: The Next Steps Forward on Energy We are committed to delivering a fully sustainable, secure, efficient, affordable and competitive all-island energy market.

4_648.text: The hallmarks of the all-island energy market will be reliable supply, highly efficient use of energy, competitive prices and sustainable, diverse energy sources.

4_649.text: This is why we are proposing a series of significant steps forward in the field of energy.

4_650.text: In government we will achieve the following commitments across each of the three energy pillars: Security of Supply

4_651.text: In government we will: Ensure that electricity supply consistently meets demand.

4_652.text: Ensure the security and reliability of gas supplies.

4_653.text: Enhance the diversity of fuels used for power generation, especially renewables.

4_654.text: Ensure the development of a landbank of state owned power generation sites to facilitate the entry of new independent generation.

4_655.text: Deliver the East/West and second North/South electricity interconnectors.

4_656.text: Deliver electricity and gas to homes and businesses over networks that are efficient, reliable and secure.

4_657.text: Create a stable, attractive environment for hydrocarbon exploration and production.

4_658.text: Mitigate the impact of any energy supply disruptions by ensuring that contingency measures are in place.

4_660.text: In government we will: Dramatically accelerate the growth of renewable energy sources in the electricity, heat and transport sectors of the economy.

4_661.text: One third of all electricity consumed will come from renewable energy by 2020.

4_662.text: Introduce co-firing at each of the three peat stations with up to 30% biomass by 2015, which will reduce greenhouse gas emissions from those three stations by 900,000 tonnes per annum and will also extend the life of those stations.

4_663.text: Implement in full, the National Bioenergy Action Plan for Ireland, which will reduce greenhouse gas emission by at least 2 million tonnes per annum.

4_664.text: Promote the enhanced deployment of green energy technologies and the sustainable use of energy in transport.

4_665.text: Introduce a biofuels obligation scheme by 2009.

4_666.text: Stimulate the development of alternative energy sources.

4_667.text: Maximise energy efficiency and energy savings across the economy with atarget of 20% energy savings by 2020 and 33% for public sector.

4_668.text: National building regulations will be updated during 2007 to reduce energy demand by 40%.

4_669.text: Support Energy Research Development and Innovation Programmes.

4_670.text: Establish a dedicated Ocean Energy Development Unit.

4_671.text: The Unit mandate will be to develop the sector and work to a target of at least 500 MW of wave and tidal energy by 2020 with an interim target of 75 MW in 2012.

4_672.text: Aim to create an export-oriented Ocean Energy sector focused on the technologies associated with this exciting sector through R&D supports and grant funding of start-up production in the sector.

4_674.text: Competitiveness In government we will: Deliver competition and consumer choice in the energy market in support of economic growth and national competitiveness.

4_675.text: Oversee the successful introduction of the Single Electricity Market in 2007.

4_676.text: Keep the electricity and gas network infrastructures, as strategic national assets, in State ownership and ensure that these assets are never privatised.

4_677.text: Oversee the transfer of transmission assets to EirGrid, establishing it as the National Transmission Grid Company by end 2008.

4_678.text: Operate ESB’s natural monopoply network business under a risk-related related rate of return, leading to reduced network tariffs which will be passed on in full to electricity customers.

4_679.text: Reduce the market power held by any one player in price-setting generation plants.

4_680.text: Ensure a sustainable future for the Semi-State Energy Enterprises.

4_681.text: Provide substantial financial support to improve the energy efficiency of existing public housing and assist those on low incomes to avoid fuel poverty.

4_682.text: Expand and develop programmes for energy conservation to ensure the most efficient use of the energy.

4_683.text: Communications When Fianna Fáil returned to office in 2002 there were very few DSL broadband lines in the State.

4_684.text: Today there are almost 520,000 broadband subscribers in Ireland, with nearly 5,000 new users a week coming on board.

4_685.text: Prices are a third of the 2002 levels and speeds are vastly improved.

4_686.text: Ireland now has the most competitively priced international connectivity in the EU.

4_687.text: Mobile phone roaming charges between the North and the Republic have also been abolished.

4_688.text: We have prioritised improvements in our postal network, with new opportunities for An Post in providing financial services.

4_689.text: In broadcasting, we have increased the powers of the ComReg to boost competition and established TG4 as an independent entity.

4_690.text: The Next Steps Forward for Communications Broadband A world-class telecommunications sector is critical to our continued economic and social prosperity.

4_691.text: We are committed to moving Ireland to the forefront of knowledge-based economies in the world through the provision of open access broadband.

4_692.text: A state-of-the-art telecommunications network will be the key infrastructure that will enable this and support information intensive industry and bandwidth-hungry citizens.

4_693.text: In government we will: Complete the roll-out of broadband throughout the country with the National Broadband Scheme (NBS).

4_694.text: This will mean that the last 10%-15% of the country, which will never have access to broadband without intervention or support, will now have access to broadband, provided on a technology-neutral basis.

4_695.text: Encourage the progressive shift to IP based Next Generation Networks.

4_696.text: Encourage the separation of Eircom’s network from its commercial retail business into a separate entity to be regulated by ComReg, on a fully open-access and transparent basis.

4_697.text: We anticipate that this organization will attract funding as a quasi-utility and will play a role in encouraging the development of Next Generation Networks in Ireland.

4_698.text: Tender contracts to provide broadband availability to the final 10% of the country.

4_699.text: The successful tenderers will have to commit to deploy technological solutions to allow maximum competition.

4_700.text: Expand the current free telephone rental scheme by providing for free broadband for older people.

4_701.text: Industry will be invited to tender for the provision of the new bundled broadband and rental service for older people.

4_702.text: Broadcasting Fianna Fáil is committed to creating an environment that encourages the maintenance of high quality Irish radio and television services by both independent broadcasters and RTÉ and securing a viable future for high quality public service broadcasting in the Irish market.

4_703.text: In government we will: Enact the Broadcasting Bill to ensure a comprehensive, modern framework of law for the sector.

4_704.text: Establish the Broadcasting Authority of Ireland.

4_705.text: Ensure a speedy right to reply to those who have been defamed in radio or television programmes.

4_706.text: Complete the pilot DTT project and complete roll-out of DTT well in advance of the EU 2012 deadline.

4_707.text: Place reviews of the licence fee on a statutory basis.

4_708.text: Provide increased funding to TG4 for increased Irish language programming.

4_709.text: Maximise the number of home-produced programmes within the RTE schedule.

4_710.text: Digitise the RTÉ archives for use in education and research.

4_711.text: Enable RTÉ to support broadcasting to the Irish community abroad.

4_712.text: Ensure a fair and competitive environment for the independent TV and radio sector.

4_713.text: Postal Services Fianna Fáil is committed to ensuring that Irish business and domestic customers enjoy competitively priced, high-quality postal services.

4_714.text: In government we will: Ensure a strong, viable post office network, which reaches into every community in Ireland and which properly remunerates all those involved in it.

4_715.text: Develop An Post as a top-class financial services entity to help in that aim.

4_716.text: Ensure that as many Government services as possible operate through the post office network.

4_717.text: Introduce a postcode system to Ireland to ensure a strong competitive postal sector and to reduce costs significantly for consumers, business and the voluntary sector.

4_718.text: Insist on much improved “next day delivery” rates and link them to any future stamp price increases.

4_719.text: Empower ComReg to withhold increases and/or clawback income where delivery targets are not met.

4_720.text: Environment Fianna Fáil has dramatically improved the protection of the Irish environment in recent years.

4_721.text: Our emphasis has always been on “environmental policies that work”.

4_722.text: Notwithstanding Ireland’s unprecedented economic and physical development over the past decade, the state of our environment has improved in most areas, thanks to pro-active policies and large-scale investment in protecting that environment.

4_723.text: As a result of our policies: Ireland is 100% compliant with EU air quality standards.

4_724.text: New waste water treatment in Dublin, Cork, Limerick, Galway and other major towns now means that Ireland is now over 90% compliant with waste water discharges in comparison with just 20% 6 years ago.

4_725.text: 96.7% of drinking water is compliant with EU standards.

4_726.text: We now have a record number of blue flag beaches – 81 in 2006.

4_727.text: Ireland’s recycling rate is up four fold on 1997 levels and our 35% recycling target was met eight years ahead of target.

4_728.text: Ireland has ratified the Kyoto Protocol on Climate Change and we are committed to meeting our international obligations.

4_729.text: We have already successfully decoupled our economic growth from growth in emissions: since 1990 our emissions grew by 23% but our economy grew by over 150%.

4_730.text: Environmental enforcement law has been strengthened and the Office of Environmental Enforcement has been established.

4_731.text: This EPA now reports that large scale illegal dumping has been successfully dealt with as a result of these policies.

4_732.text: The Environmental Performance Index presented to the 2006 Davos World Economic Forum placed Ireland 10th out of 133 countries for environmental policies.

4_733.text: The Next Steps Forward on the Environment With the scale of the environmental challenges facing the world, it is clear that serious action must go on.

4_734.text: This is why Fianna Fáil is committed to taking a further series of major steps forward for the environment during the next five years.

4_735.text: Overall, we are committed to moving Ireland into the top five in the world as measured by the Environmental Performance Index Climate Change: A Challenge for the Whole World As a developed country, as a Member State of the EU, and as a responsible nation in the wider international community, Ireland is playing its part in meeting the most important environmental issue facing the world today.

4_736.text: We have been to the fore in participating in the EU Emissions’ Trading System and will use all available mechanisms to ensure that Ireland meets its climate change commitments under the Kyoto Protocol.

4_737.text: Meeting our obligations to the future generations requires all sectors in society to play their part.

4_738.text: Fianna Fáil in Government will implement a comprehensive range of measures as set out in the new National Climate Change Strategy.

4_739.text: In particular Fianna Fáil believes in the need to commit to a clean and renewable energy future and we commit ourselves to a Green Energy Revolution.

4_740.text: In particular, we will: Increase the use of alternative energies for generating power in order to ensure that one third of electricity consumed in Ireland comes from renewable sources by 2020.

4_741.text: Create new opportunities for our farmers by moving agriculture to a new dual system of food and power production.

4_742.text: Facilitate the establishment of a new bio-fuel industry in Ireland on the back of this new agricultural production.

4_743.text: Improve the energy efficiency of new Irish homes by up to 40%.

4_744.text: Introduce a minimum requirement for the use of bio-fuels in State-owned and public transport vehicles.

4_745.text: Dublin Bus and Bus Eireann will move their existing fleet to a 5% bio-diesel blend and will achieve a 30% bio-diesel blend in their new buses.

4_746.text: Continue to use the taxation system to encourage good environmental behaviour and discourage poor practice, for example through rebalancing the VRT and Motor Tax system to reward the purchase of greener cars.

4_747.text: Complete the phasing out of incandescent light bulbs in favour of more energy efficient compact fluorescent bulbs to reduce our carbon emissions and save on electricity costs.

4_748.text: Require the public sector to lead the way on energy efficiency with a mandatory programme of efficiency measures including the sole use of energy efficient lighting and heating in offices, schools and hospitals and other public buildings to produce 33% energy savings by 2020.

4_749.text: Require all street lighting and traffic lighting systems to be energy efficient and replace inefficient systems.

4_750.text: Require carbon offsetting of all official air travel in support of urban forests.

4_751.text: Require the mandatory use of bio-fuel mixes in transport fuels and ensure that there is a nationwide bio-fuel distribution network.

4_752.text: Ensure that the development of renewable energy heating systems is encouraged through targeted grant schemes and facilitated by appropriate planning exemptions.

4_753.text: Introduce smart electricity meters and ensure that energy produced in the home and at work can be sold back into the national grid.

4_754.text: Implement all aspects of Transport 21 to so that the use of public transport becomes a real option for more and more people.

4_755.text: Put in place an Adaptation Strategy to prepare for expected changes brought about by global warming.

4_756.text: Establish a high level Commission on Climate Change to oversee implementation of the Climate Change Strategy.

4_758.text: Since 1997 there has been a mindset change in Ireland in the way we think about waste and in the way we deal with it.

4_759.text: However, we still have some way to go to reach the best standards of waste management in Europe.

4_760.text: Fianna Fáil believes in adopting best international practice to tackle the remaining waste management problems facing us.

4_761.text: In particular in Government we will: Establish new ambitious waste management targets for maximum prevention, re-use, recycling and modern waste treatment to ensure that we match the best performance in the EU for recycling with the objective that only 10% of waste or less is consigned to landfill (down from 66% now).

4_762.text: Ensure that the landfills currently provided for under regional waste management plans should be the last to be constructed for a generation.

4_763.text: Drive down the cost of waste management charges to householders and business by ensuring that our waste management system is competitive and uses all available technologies to achieve this including the use of waste for generating sustainable electricity.

4_764.text: Ensure the implementation of the National Strategy on Biodegradable Waste which aims to divert 80% of biodegradable waste from landfill through segregated collection of biodegradable waste, and the generation of compost (which will also cut down the use of peat moss).

4_765.text: Expand the network of bottle banks, recycling centres and segregated collection and introduce household hazardous waste collection (e.g. paint cans etc) in all suitable recycling centres.

4_766.text: Environmental Enforcement People or businesses which despoil the Irish countryside or break our environmental laws should be punished and should make good any damage caused.

4_767.text: We established the Office of Environmental Enforcement in 2004 to lead the fight against environmental crime with the result that large scale illegal dumping has now ceased.

4_768.text: In government we will: Review the level of fines and custodial sentences which can be applied by the lower Courts (where the majority of prosecutions are taken) in cases of pollution, dumping, illegal developments and other environmental crimes, so that thepunishment fits the crime.

4_769.text: Ensure that the lower Courts can impose harsher sentences where corporate bodies are guilty of the offence.

4_771.text: Despite steady improvements in recent years, the problem of litter in Ireland is still far too widespread.

4_772.text: Fianna Fáil has eliminated most plastic bag litter through the plastic bag levy and we put in place an imaginative, industry-funded awareness campaign to address the issue of chewing gum.

4_773.text: In government we will: Increase support to initiatives such as Irish Business Against Litter and the Green Schools Programme which raise awareness on litter issues.

4_774.text: Use the nationwide roll out of the Community Warden Service to increase litter enforcement.

4_775.text: Incentivise local action in dealing with litter, including introducing programmes such as the “adopt-a-highway” for both main and secondary roads.

4_776.text: Examine the use of the penalty points system to deter litter being thrown out of vehicles and the dumping of litter by the wayside.

4_777.text: Protecting our Water Recent investment has resulted in increased wastewater treatment capacity equivalent to the needs of 3.1 million people and additional drinking water treatment capacity equivalent to the needs of 1 million people.

4_778.text: The quality of our drinking water and the water in our rivers and lakes have shown significant improvement because of this investment.

4_779.text: Ireland is the leading country in the EU for implementation of the Water Framework Directive which aims to protect our rivers and lakes.

4_781.text: Over the next 5 years Fianna Fáil will work to ensure that Ireland’s waters are the most pristine in Europe.

4_782.text: We will: Finish the job of upgrading all our local group water schemes to match the highest drinking water standards.

4_783.text: Ensure that public water supplies deliver a reliable service that are 100% compliant with drinking water standards.

4_784.text: Continue with our investment in waste water schemes to ensure that discharges into our rivers and lakes meet the highest international standards.

4_785.text: Implement higher standards of water protection and ensure that farmers in particular have all necessary supports to operate to these standards.

4_786.text: Ensure that coastal bathing water compliance rises from 96% to 100% and increase the number of Blue Flag beaches around the country.

4_787.text: Introduce a scheme of support for the replacement and upgrade of septic tanks older than 15 years with newer systems.

4_788.text: Air Quality The Environmental Protection Agency has reported that Ireland is now in compliance with 100% of the EU air quality standards for all pollutants.

4_789.text: However, we want to further improve standards, particularly relating to emissions from the transport sector.

4_790.text: In government we will: Expand the network of air quality monitoring stations to improve national coverage.

4_791.text: Introduce new standards for substances not previously controlled, eg.

4_793.text: Ensure compliance with new limits on fine particulate matter PM10, generated by vehicle engines.

4_794.text: Chemicals Thousands of chemicals in everyday use have not been adequately tested for their impact on the environment and human health.

4_795.text: The EU has adopted a comprehensive regulatory framework governing the manufacturing and use of chemicals used in Europe with the view to protecting human health and the environment and enhancing competitiveness.

4_796.text: We will implement this initiative as a matter of priority in a way which does not impact on the competitiveness of our economy.

4_797.text: Dublin Bay We will establish a Dublin Bay Area Task Force to maximise the potential of the Bay for the people of our capital city.

4_798.text: Environmental Technologies We will support the development of Environmental Technologies in Ireland to achieve a win/win situation of improved competitiveness and environmental performance Built Heritage

4_799.text: In government we will: Complete the national survey of our built heritage within the term of the next Government so that the best of our heritage is protected under our planning laws to a common and consistent standard across the country.

4_800.text: Work on a North/South basis to increase the protection available for the 2,200 remaining thatched cottages in Ireland.

4_801.text: Support the work of the newly established Irish Heritage Trust.

4_802.text: Update and consolidate the law on national monuments to maximise and clarify the protection provided to our archaeological heritage.

4_803.text: Seek designation of Clonmacnoise as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

4_805.text: In government we will: Complete the designation of those remaining areas proposed for conservation purposes.

4_806.text: Work with farmers and other landowners by putting in place management plans to ensure the long-term protection of these valuable conservation areas.

4_807.text: Resource the national Biological Records Centre as central database to record the richness of Ireland’s flora and fauna and as centre of research excellence.

4_808.text: Work on an all-Ireland basis to protect threatened species and reintroduce species which have disappeared from Ireland.

4_809.text: Nuclear Energy and Sellafield Fianna Fáil recommits to a policy of non-nuclear power and we strongly believe that nuclear power is neither sustainable nor an answer to Ireland’s energy needs.

4_810.text: Nuclear power fails on grounds of environmental risk and long term economic costs.

4_811.text: We also continue to believe that Sellafield poses an unacceptable risk.

4_812.text: In government we will: Continue to bring political, diplomatic and legal efforts to bear on the UK with a view to securing the safe decommissioning of all nuclear reprocessing facilities at Sellafield.

4_813.text: Press at EU level for the establishment of a strong independent EU Agency to inspect nuclear installations across the EU.

4_815.text: The Irish tourism and hospitality industry is one of the most successful sectors of Irish-owned enterprise, supporting in the region of 250,000 jobs.

4_816.text: In Government we have worked hard to grow the number of overseas visitors from five million in 1997 to 7.7 million in 2006.

4_817.text: With new strategies to attract tourists to the regions, the economic, social and cultural benefits of this growth have been felt throughout the country.

4_818.text: We have placed tourism at the heart of the National Development Plan 2007-2013, setting out an investment programme of 3800 million in the industry.

4_819.text: The Next Steps Forward on Tourism Irish tourism is now at an important point in its evolution.

4_820.text: The market place is changing rapidly, presenting our tourism sector with both challenges and opportunities.

4_821.text: Fianna Fáil is committed to building on the growth we have achieved and sustained since the 1990s.

4_822.text: We are confident that, working with industry, the targets set out in the New Horizons Programme will be met, namely ten million overseas visitors generating 36 billion by 2012.

4_823.text: We believe the keys to continued success in an increasingly competitive marketplace will be product investment and innovation, enhanced access, creative destination marketing and human resource management.

4_824.text: Cost competitiveness will remain critical to the future well-being of Irish tourism.

4_825.text: However, it is only one of the many dimensions of overall competitiveness.

4_826.text: Ireland must maintain its appeal on the basis of successful management of our other competitive advantages.

4_827.text: Our goal, with industry, will be to deliver a quality value-for-money experience that vindicates the price.

4_828.text: We are determined to ensure that Ireland is a destination of choice for more international and domestic tourists, with a tourism experience that exceeds expectations in terms of friendliness, quality of environment, diversity and depth of culture.

4_829.text: This will be our unique selling point and will be central to our Next Steps for Irish tourism.

4_830.text: Product Investment and Innovation Fianna Fáil recognises that investment is needed to ensure that our tourism product is among the best in the world and maximises the potential of our environment and heritage.

4_831.text: In government we will: Provide 3300 million to assist the industry, tourism agencies and local authorities in delivering the ambitious world-class product outlined in Failte Ireland’s Tourism Product Development Strategy 2007 –2013.

4_832.text: Place much greater emphasis on the protection, conservation, interpretation and access to Ireland’s natural and built heritage.

4_833.text: Deepen North/South cooperation in tourism, building in particular on the success of Tourism Ireland as a dynamic and innovative cross-border body leading the way on mutually advantageous all-island economic co-operation.

4_834.text: Establish, through Fáilte Ireland, an innovation fund to promote and support the development of tourism products that are new to the Irish market and to promote best practice, particularly in terms of environmental sustainability and accessibility for tourists with disabilities.

4_835.text: Develop with Fáilte Ireland, rural-based package-style holidays through which B & B owners and Farm Holiday operators can offer activities such as walking, angling, golfing and cycling in addition to the provision of accommodation and quality home cooked meals.

4_836.text: Develop a rolling programme of national culture, musical and literary festivals to enhance the Irish tourism product, in particular through the establishment of a new fund of 328 million for the creation of a small number of major annual events over the period to 2013.

4_837.text: Work with Fáilte Ireland and Tourism Ireland to capitalise on the beauty of the Irish countryside and promote Ireland as a healthy activity holiday destination for walking, cycling, angling, golfing, sailing, equestrian and marine holidays.

4_838.text: Enhanced Access Fianna Fáil realises that affordable and efficient transport links to and within Ireland are absolutely crucial for attracting more visitors and spreading the benefits throughout the regions.

4_839.text: In government we will: Open Terminal 2 at Dublin Airport in 2009.

4_840.text: Enhance the capacity of the regional airports to attract more direct international services through the 386 million Regional Airports Capital Grant scheme.

4_841.text: Make rural locations more readily accessible for tourists on shorter visits through the delivery of the extensive plans outlined in Transport 21.

4_842.text: Creative Marketing Further developing the potential of existing markets will be a priority in the years ahead, while growing new markets will bring new opportunities.

4_843.text: Realising the potential of the business, sports and eco-tourism areas will be vital for new growth, as will making the most of the internet as a marketing and booking tool.

4_844.text: In government we will: Invest 3335 million under the National Development Plan in marketing Irish Tourism.

4_845.text: Seize the opportunities presented by the Open Skies arrangement with the US to substantially grow the number of US visitors.

4_846.text: To this end, we will provide significant infrastructural development in the Mid West area, as well as marketing support to the Shannon region for a transitional period to help consolidate existing markets and develop new sources of business.

4_847.text: Build on the opportunities presented by the increasing availability of low cost flights from mainland Europe and the UK.

4_848.text: Undertake a strategic review of new and developing markets to identify the investment and actions needed to realise their potential.

4_849.text: Put in place a strong promotional programme for the new National Conference Centre in Dublin with a view to doubling the level of business tourism to Ireland from 3400 million to 3800 million per year over the next ten years.

4_850.text: We will also investigate the feasibility of a Regional Conference Centre in the Shannon/Limerick area.

4_851.text: Encourage the Tourism Agencies to highlight our National Games to a greater degree in their promotional activities and continue the policy of attracting suitable major sporting events to Ireland.

4_852.text: Seek, with the Tourism Agencies and Local Authorities, suitable areas to develop and promote eco tourism, as well as enhancing the existing Northwest Project, the Green Box.

4_853.text: Invest in new information and communication technologies for marketing and customer relations management and training.

4_854.text: Work with the Regional Tourism Development Boards in conjunction with Local Authorities and the Tourism Industry to develop comprehensive, interactive local area tourism web sites carrying details of all possibilities in an area for tourists and with a booking facility.

4_855.text: Competing Through People With 6,000 new workers expected to join the tourism sector each year to the end of this decade, human resource development will be one of the most vital issues affecting the further development and success of tourism.

4_856.text: The addition of an ever-growing multicultural workforce can enhance our tourism product, if they are supported in acquiring skills they will need to enable them to make an effective contribution.

4_857.text: We will: Invest 3149 million under the National Development Plan 2007-2013 in training and human resources in the tourism sector.

4_858.text: Implement in full the Fáilte Ireland ‘Competing through People’ programme, which looks to people working in the Industry as a principal source of competitive advantage, and their skills as a key variable in delivering strong business results.

4_859.text: Agriculture, Food & Forestry Farmers understand better than anyone the scale of challenges they face through globalisation and development.

4_860.text: While farming is no longer a dominant part of our economy, Fianna Fáil absolutely believes that it plays a vital part in the social and economic life of our country which must be supported now and in the years ahead.

4_861.text: In this period of rapid transformation, we have worked hard with farmers to support them and to help them to compete.

4_862.text: One of the biggest changes has been the scale of national resources which are now devoted to agriculture – representing a sustained commitment to supporting farmers even where EU supports are not available or are being reduced.

4_863.text: Of the overall funding of 38.7 billion provided in the new National Development Plan for the agri-food sector, a total of 36.6 billion will come from the national exchequer.

4_864.text: We have faced criticism from many in opposition for the amount of resources and time spent supporting farmers – including our consistent fight against unfair trade deals and an anti-farmer reform of the CAP.

4_865.text: We are proud of our stance and remain absolutely committed to ensuring that farmers have a strong influence over government policy.

4_866.text: The Next Steps Forward for Agriculture, Food & Forestry

4_867.text: The next five years will be critical in many areas for the entire sector.

4_868.text: WTO and CAP “Health Check” negotiations will be concluded and it will be necessary to provide a systematic programme of investment and reform to help farmers meet the many challenges ahead.

4_869.text: This is why we are proposing a series of ambitious next steps forward for farming, forestry and the food industry and why we are saying that this area will be one of the key priorities for us in government.

4_871.text: Our programme is based on achieving certain key objectives: Support farm families in order to maximise their choice on how they farm.

4_872.text: Significantly reduce the regulatory burdens faced by farmers.

4_873.text: Invest in developing the new products and new food markets which will bring long-term security for the sector.

4_874.text: We will maintain a strong, independent Agriculture and Food Department and ensure that agriculture is given a high priority in any future programme for government.

4_875.text: Global Challenges & Negotiations As decisions affecting Irish farmers are increasingly internationalised, the strongest possible leadership for Irish agriculture is required at the world’s negotiating tables.

4_876.text: We are committed to providing this leadership.

4_877.text: We are also committed to working for ease of access to all markets where demand arises, ahead of our competitors.

4_878.text: In government we will: Secure the highest achievable level of support for the farming sector at EU and WTO levels.

4_879.text: Continue to protect direct payments to farmers, ensure the export subsidies are dealt with in a balanced and equitable way, and promote the need for non-trade issues to be part of any further trade deals.

4_880.text: Do all that is required to protect Irish consumers from imports of agricultural produce that do not meet the same standards as those required of Irish farmers.

4_881.text: Oppose any moves to restrict the live export of animals.
